Description: Torso of terracotta figure of Isis (?) or one of her devotees. The torso fragment of a devotee of Isis, or she may be Isis herself. She wears the Isis-mantle draped from her right shoulder, caught up and knotted under her breasts, with her left shoulder bare. Her right arm, mostly broken away, is raised, and her left arm, apparently entirely missing, was probably lowered by her side. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt, varying to redbrown.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparandum. Not unlike Beck and Bol 1983: 510, no. 117, a figure of Isis dated to the Roman period, which has one bared breast, a raised right hand holding a sistrum or a cobra, and lowered left hand holding a situla.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3160)
Condition: The back is lost. Right arm most broken away, left arm completely lost.
